itemDescription: Welsh rugby union and rugby league footballer

wikipedia_page.main: Evan Williams (18 June 1906 – 18 November 1976) was a Welsh rugby union, and professional rugby league footballer who played in the 1920s and 1930s. He played representative level rugby union (RU) for Wales, and at club level for Aberavon RFC as a centre, i.e. number 12 or 13, and club level rugby league (RL) for Leeds, as a goal-kicking centre, stand-off or scrum-half, i.e. number 3 or 4, 6, or 7,

response: * Evan Williams (Internet entrepreneur) (born 1972), entrepreneur, Blogger and Twitter co-founder

* Evan Williams (diplomat), Australian diplomat and Administrator of the Australian Indian Ocean Territories
* Evan Williams (rugby) (1906–1976), rugby union and rugby league footballer of the 1920s
* Sir Evan Williams, 1st Baronet (1871–1959), Welsh industrialist
* Evan Williams (actor), Canadian actor and musician
* Evan Williams (squash player) (born 1989), New Zealand squash player
* Evan Williams (whiskey), brand of bourbon whiskey

After an impressive start to the 2010 season, in October 2010, he was selected to the 33-man squad for the Autumn international series. On 11 November 2010, North was named in the Wales team to face South Africa on 13 November, making him the joint-third youngest player to represent Wales behind Tom Prydie and Norman Biggs and equal to Evan Williams. North made an impressive start to his international career on 13 November 2010 in a match against the reigning world champions, by scoring two tries for Wales as they lost to South Africa 29–25 at the Millennium Stadium in Cardiff. He set a number of Welsh and international records in the match:
